author: Joanna Mather
title: Treasurer Joe Hockey to consider Labor's Warren Buffett rule
text:
Treasurer Joe Hockey says he's happy to look at Labor's Buffett rule Bloomberg by Joanna Mather Treasurer Joe Hockey says he'll consider Labor's "Buffett rule" proposal, which would set a minimum tax rate of 35Â¢ in the dollar for anybody earning over $300,000.
The ALP national conference agreed on Friday to consider adopting an Australian version of the rule named after by US billionaire Warren Buffett.
Mr Hockey told ABC radio on Monday that he was seeking more information from Labor frontbencher Anthony Albanese, who successfully lobbied for a motion that requires a future Labor government to at the very least consider the rule.
Australia needed to be careful about pushing tax rates so high as to encourage high-income earners to move overseas, Mr Hockey added.
"Fifty per cent of all income tax in Australia is paid by 10 per cent of the working population," he said.
"If you don't get the formula right, you are going to see mobility in that 10 per cent of the workforce where they can go and work overseas in a way that our parents and grandparents could never have imagined.
Mr Hockey said Labor has six years in government to put the rule in place, but he was nonetheless "happy to look at it".
Taxable incomes cut to zero The Australian Buffett rule is based on a paper written by The Australia Institute, which estimates that 31,500 households would be forced to pay an average of $79,053 more tax a year .
The paper cites Tax Office statistics that show 75 individuals earned more than $1 million in 2011-12, but paid no income tax.
"They did this by finding tax deductions that reduced their taxable incomes to levels below the income tax threshold," the paper says.
"In total, these 75 people had pre-tax income of $195 million, but reduced their taxable income to a mere $82. Each of these individuals earned more than a million dollars for the year but had an average taxable income of just $1.09."
But tax experts have said there could be many legitimate expenses that may reduce taxable income to zero such as investing in a loss-making business.
Mr Hockey also indicated there could be reasons for this if, for example, if people were investing in start-ups or innovative businesses.
A paper released as part of the tax reform debate last month shows the wealthy use negative gearing, donations and professional fees as part of strategies to reduce their tax.
